<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 324, 293]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 368, 317]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 99, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 735, 95]]<|/det|>
The cubic equation \(x^{3} + bx^{2} + d = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma\), where \(\alpha = \beta\) and \(d \neq 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 107, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 358, 125]]<|/det|>
Show that \(4b^{3} + 27d = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 603, 185, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 603, 571, 621]]<|/det|>
Given that \(2\alpha^{2} + \gamma^{2} = 3b\), find the values of \(b\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 603, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 144, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 76, 777, 100]]<|/det|>
By considering \(\left(2r + 1\right)^{3} - \left(2r - 1\right)^{3}\), use the method of differences to prove that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 112, 608, 156]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{n}r^{2} = \frac{1}{6} n(n + 1)(2n + 1). \quad [5]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 79, 648, 102]]<|/det|>
Let \(S_{n} = 1^{2} + 3 \times 2^{2} + 3^{2} + 3 \times 4^{2} + 5^{2} + 3 \times 6^{2} + \ldots + \left(2 + \left(-1\right)^{n}\right)n^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 112, 146, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 111, 792, 133]]<|/det|>
Show that \(S_{2n} = \frac{1}{3} n(2n + 1)(an + b)\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers to be determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 920, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 695, 176, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 693, 369, 720]]<|/det|>
State the value of \(\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{S_{2n}}{n^3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 698, 918, 717]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 900, 92]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\varPi\) contains the lines \(\mathbf{r} = 3\mathbf{i} - 2\mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k} + \lambda (- \mathbf{i} + 2\mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k})\) and \(\mathbf{r} = 4\mathbf{i} + 4\mathbf{j} + 2\mathbf{k} + \mu (3\mathbf{i} + 2\mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 104, 144, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 792, 123]]<|/det|>
Find a Cartesian equation of \(\varPi\), giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 104, 918, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 92, 94, 112]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 695, 120]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is given by \(\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{2}\sqrt{2} & -\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{2} \\ \frac{1}{2}\sqrt{2} & \frac{1}{2}\sqrt{2} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & k \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\), where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 138, 144, 156]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 724, 156]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents a sequence of two geometrical transformations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 168, 855, 188]]<|/det|>
State the type of each transformation, and make clear the order in which they are applied. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 183, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 448, 737, 467]]<|/det|>
The triangle \(ABC\) in the \(x - y\) plane is transformed by \(\mathbf{M}\) onto triangle \(DEF\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 478, 839, 497]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(k\), the single matrix which transforms triangle \(DEF\) onto triangle \(ABC\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 165, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 560, 915, 579]]<|/det|>
<form>Find, in terms of \(k\), the single matrix which transforms triangle \(DEF\) onto triangle \(ABC\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 599, 165, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 599, 915, 618]]<|/det|>
<form>Find, in terms of \(k\), the single matrix which transforms triangle \(DEF\) onto triangle \(ABC\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 638, 165, 656]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 638, 915, 656]]<|/det|>
<form>Find, in terms of \(k\), the single matrix which transforms triangle \(DEF\) onto triangle \(ABC\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 165, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 675, 915, 694]]<|/det|>
<form>Find, in terms of \(k\), the single matrix which transforms triangle \(DEF\) onto triangle \(ABC\). [2]

<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 714, 915, 732]]<|/det|>
<form>Find, in terms of \(k\), the single matrix which transforms triangle \(DEF\) onto triangle \(ABC\). [2]

<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 752, 915, 771]]<|/det|>
<form>Find, in terms of \(k\), the single matrix which transforms triangle \(DEF\) onto triangle \(ABC\). [2]

<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 790, 915, 809]]<|/det|>
<form>Find, in terms of \(k\), the single matrix which transforms triangle \(DEF\) onto triangle \(ABC\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 828, 165, 847]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 828, 915, 847]]<|/det|>
<form>Find, in terms of \(k\), the single matrix which transforms triangle \(DEF\) onto triangle \(ABC\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 866, 165, 885]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 866, 915, 885]]<|/det|>
<form>Find, in terms of \(k\), the single matrix which transforms triangle \(DEF\) onto triangle \(ABC\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 904, 165, 923]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 904, 915, 923]]<|/det|>
<form>Find, in terms of \(k\), the single matrix which transforms triangle \(DEF\) onto triangle \(ABC\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(k\) for which the transformation represented by \(\mathbf{M}\) has no invariant lines through the origin.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 84, 920, 102]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 504, 89]]<|/det|>
Show that the curve with Cartesian equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 97, 593, 122]]<|/det|>
\[\left(x^{2} + y^{2}\right)^{2} = 36\left(x^{2} - y^{2}\right)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 131, 425, 152]]<|/det|>
has polar equation \(r^2 = 36\cos 2\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 412, 643, 433]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r^2 = 36\cos 2\theta\), for \(- \frac{1}{4}\pi \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{4}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 146, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 720, 463]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\) and state the maximum distance of a point on \(C\) from the pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 96, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 76, 416, 103]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{5x^2}{5x - 2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 144, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 487, 131]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 918, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 453, 186, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 453, 547, 472]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 453, 918, 472]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 235, 88]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 89]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 408, 146, 427]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 401, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \left|\frac{5x^2}{5x - 2}\right|\) and find in exact form the set of values of \(x\) for which \(\left|\frac{5x^2}{5x - 2}\right| < 2.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 440, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
